text: On which appears:

head_text.speaker/title: EVERYTHING YOU ARE ABOUT TO SEE, HAPPENED

text: The words slowly FADE OUT, taking us hard into
A small, pleasant house on a tree-lined street in Los Ang circa 1928. 210 North Avenue 23. Not far from Dodger Stad SUPERIMPOSE: LOS ANGELES, MARCH 9, 1928.

A Bakelite alarm clock hits 6:30 A.M. and RINGS. CHRISTIN COLLINS, thirties, attractive, rumpled, reaches INTO FRAM shut it off. She sits up, rubs tiredly at her face, and m OS, switching on a radio as she goes. Music fills the air

She throws water on her face as the music continues. She looks at herself in the mirror as the light flickers over She hits the wall offhandedly, something she does every d The flickering stops. With a last look at the mirror, she smoothes back her hair and exits, switching off the light

Dressed now, she flicks on the overhead light. WALTER COL is nine years old, with light brown hair, though we don't much of it or him, he's entangled in the sheets. It's important that we don't see him too clearly in most of th following scenes, but without drawing attention to that a
Walter...time for school, honey.
She sits on the edge of the bed, runs a hand through his
Just ten more minutes --
Sorry, champ. (more)
CHANGELING A True Story CHRISTINE (Cont'd) You can sleep in all you want tomorrow, that's what Saturdays are for. Now hurry up or your breakfast will get cold.
It's cereal, it's supposed to be cold.
She smiles, kisses him on the forehead, and exits. He sit on the edge of the bed, wavers, then falls back into bed
A street-car (known then as the Big Red) rumbles down the street in the gray light of morning, passing Ford Model A and Hudsons and Nash four-door sedans.

Christine sits on one of the benches, Walter's face burie her lap, still half-asleep. She nudges him as they come t an intersection by a grade school. It's early enough that only a few other kids have arrived.
We're here, sweetie.   Come on.

She hands him a sack lunch and follows as he slouches tow the door. She watches from the curb as he heads toward th school. Some of the teachers lounging outside nod to her Walter approaches, so she knows they're aware that he's t She waves, then hurriedly gets back on the street-car as rumbles away.

Located on Grand Avenue downtown, the huge switchboard ro is a maze of switching stations, tangles of wires and hea wooden headsets...a roar of buzzers, bells, circuits open and closing, and a hundred female operators speaking at o Supervisors on skates roll up and down the narrow lanes c by the banks of switching stations, going from one operat to another as needed. Christine is one of them. She turns at the SOUND of a bell struck twice, then rolls down the toward an OPERATOR frantically waving a pink sheet of pap
Okay Sandy, what's the prob--
The mortified operator hands her the headset and stalks o CHANGELING A True Story
You deal with this one, I'm not going near it.
Christine struggles on the headset.

Hello? Yes, this is the supervisor, ma'am, what can I -- (checks board) Yes, I can see that you're on a party line, ma'am, what can I -- (beat) I know, it's unfortunate, but people sometimes do listen in on party lines. We hope to have private lines installed by -- (beat) Well, what's he doing when you're on the phone? (beat) Are you sure? Maybe there's a problem with the phone line. He could be asthmatic, or -- (beat) Oh. No, I...I've never heard of anything like that before either. Guess there's a first time for everything, right? No, I'm afraid there's nothing we can do about people abusing the equipment or... themselves. I'm sorry. I --
She reacts to the phone being hung up hard at the other e as the floor manager, BEN HARRIS, 30s, approaches.
Everything all right?
Fine, Mr. Harris...fine...just someone having a problem with a... with the connection.
Tell them to take the plug and shove it in and out a few times, that'll usually do it.
Unfortunately that was part of the problem. If you'll excuse me....
She roller-skates off toward another operator waving anot pink sheet of paper. CHANGELING A True Story

Christine sits alone, eating a bag lunch and reading a th telephone company manual. Working hard to advance herself Then a bell rings: time to return to work. Other employee gather up their belongings and start inside. As Christine closes the book, her bookmark falls out. As she picks it we see that it's a child's drawing: her and Walter (with indicating who is who) on a green hill, under an orange s She touches the drawing and smiles as the bell rings agai She grabs her belongs and heads back inside.
Christine waits outside the school as another bell rings, announcing the end of classes. Kids run outside, Walter a them. He folds in alongside as they start down the sidewa
Hey, sport.
Hey, mom.
So how was school?
Okay. We learned about dinosaurs, and I got in a fight with Billy Mankowski.
What happened?
He hit me.
Did you hit him back? (he nods) Good. Rule number one: Never start a fight, but always finish it. So why did he hit you?
Because I hit him.
She stops, looks at him.
Wait...you hit him first? (he nods) Why?
CHANGELING A True Story
He said my dad ran off because he didn't like me.
Your dad never even had a chance to meet you...so how could he not like you?
Then why did he leave?
Christine takes his hand, and they continue down the side

Well, the same day you were born, something else arrived. It came in the mail, in a box just slightly bigger than you. You know what was in that box? (he shakes head) Something called responsibility. Now, to some people, responsibility is fun, it's what you live your whole life for. Other people think it's the scariest thing in the world.
So he ran away because he was scared of what was in the box?
Yup.
That's dumb.
That's what I thought.
She turns and crouches down in front of him.

Walter, I decided a long time ago that I would always tell you the truth, that I would treat you like a grown-up. I can't expect you to respect me unless I respect you. (beat) I've never lied to you. Your father leaving had nothing to do with you, and everything to do with what was in the responsibility box.
Pinky-swear?
CHANGELING A True Story
Pinky-swear.
She takes his pinky in hers, gives a tug.    He smiles.
First one to the corner store gets ice cream!
He laughs and tears off. She runs after him, letting him stay ahead of her the whole way.
Walter is asleep on the floor, in front of the radio, whi is playing the closing moments of Amos and Andy. Christin enters and turns off the radio. He stirs, looks up at her
Did I miss Amos and Andy?
I'm afraid so, sport.   Come on now, time for bed.
She picks him up and carries him up the stairs.
Are we still going to the movies tomorrow?
Uh-huh. I hear there's a new Charlie Chaplin playing down at Grauman's, and a new serial called The Mysterious Airman.
Who's that?
I don't know. Nobody does. That's what makes him so mysterious.
Oh.   Am I too heavy for you to carry?
Not for years yet, Walter.     Not for years.
And she disappears upstairs.
Just enough to bring us into CHANGELING A True Story
She's getting ready for the day and is almost out of the when the phone rings. She hesitates, then picks it up.

Hello? (beat) Oh, hello, Margaret. I'm fine, thanks. No, I was just -- (beat) You're kidding. When did she call in sick? (checks watch) What about Myrna? I know she could use the extra hours. Oh. No, it's just...I promised Walter I'd take him to the movies today. There has to be somebody else.... (beat) All right, I...guess we can do it tomorrow. I'll get there as soon as I can. But just until four, okay? See you in a bit.
She hangs up. She doesn't like this, but there's no way o of it. She straightens and heads out of the room.
A disappointed Walter sits on the couch as Christine puts things together quickly.
There's a sandwich and milk in the icebox, and I've asked Mrs. Riley if her daughter can stop by in a couple of hours, just to --
I can take care of myself.
Of course you can. She's coming by to check on the house, not you.
She stops in front of him, kneels down to eye height.
Tomorrow, we'll go to the movies. Then we'll ride the Big Red down to Santa Monica and walk on the pier. How's that? That okay? (more)
CHANGELING A True Story CHRISTINE (Cont'd) (he nods) Good. I'll be back before it gets dark.
I'm not afraid of the dark.     I'm not afraid of anything.
I know you're not, honey. That's how I raised you. (kisses his head) Be good. See you in a bit.
She heads out, the screen door clattering shut behind her
She crosses the lawn and turns at the sidewalk, glancing as Walter looks out at her from the window. She waves. He waves back. With one last look, she continues off.
If the place was hectic before, now it's even worse: line buzzing, voices chattering, operators following Christine around with papers and question.
We've got lines jammed from here to Ohio...he insists on talking to someone in charge...I've tried everything and the console's just dead...I need your signature here for a supply requisition....
Christine glances up at the clock, 4:39.    She's already But she does what's necessary.
All right, get me the Omaha routing station, see if we can put the calls through their switchers...and let's get that console running....
She hurries off to take care of it all, the others follow
START on a clock which reads 5:20, then TILT DOWN as Chri comes out of the switchboard room, pulling on a sweater, to leave...as the floor manager steps out of his office. CHANGELING A True Story
Christine...good, I was hoping to catch you. I've been following your work reports, and I just want you to know that I'm very impressed.
She glances down the block. The street car is approaching but she doesn't want to piss off her boss by running off.
When I first suggested hiring female supervisors, my superiors weren't big on the idea. But you've held your own as well as any of our male supervisors, and --
Thank you, Mr. Harris, but I --
Ben, please. Point is, we're looking for someone to take on a managerial position in our new Beverly Hills office. If you're interested I can --
That's great, Mr. Harris, I really appreciate the vote of confidence.
Good, good...so maybe we could --
She looks up to see the streetcar right at the stop.
I'm sorry, but I really have to go. We'll talk on Monday. Good night!
She races out to
running after the streetcar as it closes its doors.
Wait...wait...hold on, just a --
But the streetcar rumbles away before she can catch it. Frustrated, she glances at her watch and sighs resignedly
Christine sits on the front bench, watching as the shadow lengthen, then pulls the bell. The car rumbles to a stop she steps out onto the sidewalk. CHANGELING A True Story

She passes a grocery store, where a clock reads 6:15, and continues past other houses on the pleasant, green street We HEAR parents telling their kids to come in for dinner, radios playing music or radio dramas. Peaceful, charming. Christine smiles, turns the corner, looks to her house -- -- and it's dark, closed up. No lights on inside, no musi or dramas on the radio. Dead silent. Christine pauses, then picks up her pace. No need to pani he could be upstairs asleep, could be in the back of the where the lights wouldn't show. She goes to the front door.     It's unlocked.    She ent
It's dark, silent.    She puts her purse down.     Looks
Walter?
Nothing.   She goes into
switching on lights as she goes. Nothing. She checks the refrigerator. The sandwich she made Walter is untouched. She moves to the staircase.
Walter...?
She opens the door to his room.      No Walter.
She crosses to the sidewalk.     Looks up and down the st
Walter?   Honey? Time to come in.
A little GIRL on a tricycle rolls past.
Susie honey, have you seen Walter?
Nuh-uh.
The girl continues away. Christine's concerned, but she h hit the panic button, not yet. She crosses the street to CHANGELING A True Story
-- and rings the doorbell.       The door opens and MRS. forties, emerges.
Mrs. Riley, I'm sorry to bother you at dinnertime, but I was wondering if Walter was here.
No, I'm afraid not.
Do you know if Jamie was able to look in on him?
Well, I mentioned it to her, but she was going to a dance with some of her friends...you know how teenagers are. Is everything all right?
I'm sure it's fine, I just... (beat) Thank you, Mrs. Riley.
Christine heads away.
Christine stops at the sidewalk in front of her house, lo up and down the street, arms folded against the growing c
Walter...?     Walter....

She starts walking again. Faster now. Looking around tree and porches, anywhere a nine-year-old boy might hide. She hears children playing. Laughing. She picks up her pace, homing in on the sound. She turns the corner to find three children playing, none them Walter. She looks down the ominously empty streets. Her worry growing, she heads to the house.       Faster n clicking on the hard sidewalk.
She bursts in, leaving the door open, looking around in c he came in while she was out. Nothing. She crosses to the phone, hesitates for just a BEAT, then picks up the recei CHANGELING A True Story
Yes, Operator, give me the police.
There's a long pause as she waits, looks out the window, POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) Lincoln Heights Division.
Yes, hello, my name is Christine Collins, I live at 210 North Avenue 23...I'm calling to report a missing child...it's my son, he.... POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) How long has he been gone?
I'm not sure...I just got home from work and...it could be since late this morning, it could be just an hour -- POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) Have you checked around the neighborhood?
Yes, of course, I -- POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) Maybe he lost track of the time.

No, he always stays around the house when it starts to get dark. Can you please send someone down here? POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) I'm sorry, but our policy is that we don't dispatch units on missing child cases for twenty-four hours.

What?   But that's -- POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) Ninety-nine times out of a hundred the kid shows up by morning. We don't have the resources to go chasing every kid who runs off with his pals and --
That's not Walter, he doesn't do that.
CHANGELING A True Story POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) With all due respect, ma'am, every parent who calls us says the same thing.
Please, I -- POLICE DISPATCHER (on phone) I'm sorry, but there's nothing I can do. I'll take your name and information, but that's all until tomorrow morning at the earliest.
Christine walks down the street, arms wrapped around hers
I'm sure he'll show up by then. They always do.
She continues on, calling Walter's name as she disappears into the shadows.

Christine watches out the curtained living room windows, red rimmed from worry but not from tears, not yet, as a p car finally pulls up. Neighbors look on as the officers g out and approach the house. HOLD on Christine's face, pal and worried, UNDER:
Our thoughts go out again to Mrs. Christine Collins, of Lincoln Heights --
Located at 5100 Coliseum Street
-- whose young son, Walter Collins, disappeared almost two weeks ago.

A large radio microphone with the call letters KGF is ato podium, where PASTOR GUSTAV BRIEGLEB stands: fifties, bar chested, no-nonsense, a fire-and-brimstone preacher. His congregation sits in hard wooden pews, listening and nodd
Though she is not a member of our congregation, we pray for her today (more)

CHANGELING A True Story REV. BRIEGLEB (Cont'd) as we have every day since we first learned of her situation on the radio, and in the newspapers. (beat) We are told that the Los Angeles Police Department is doing the best it can to reunite mother and child, and I am sure that is true. (beat) But given its position as the most violent, corrupt and incompetent police department this side of the Rocky Mountains, that's not saying a great deal.
There's APPLAUSE and cheering from the pews.   He lets it

Every day, new bodies show up along Mulholland, or in ditches, the work of Police Chief James Davis and his so-called "gun squad." Every day the needs of honest citizens are put second to greed and personal gain. Every day, the city sinks deeper into a cesspool of fear, intimidation and corruption. Once the City of Angels, Los Angeles is now a place where our protectors have become our brutalizers...where to be the law...is to be above the law...where none dare speak truth to power. (beat) But we will not be silent. We will continue to put their offenses and their failures in full view of the public. We will not be intimidated.
The place erupts into applause and cheering.

POLICE CHIEF JAMES E. DAVIS, 40s, hard-edged and tall, st looking out the window as the radio drones on behind him. REV. BRIEGLEB (on radio) Because while the "gun squad" speaks in the only language Chief Davis understands, we speak in the language of compassion, truth and strength. We speak for our fellow citizens, beaten and killed by a renegade police department. (more)

CHANGELING A True Story REV. BRIEGLEB (on radio) (Cont'd) We speak for an innocent child, ripped from his mother's arms, now all but forgotten by the police. And that voice, my friends, will never be silenced.
More cheers and applause as Davis switches off the radio.
The alarm goes off, but Christine is already awake. Stari up at the ceiling. She slowly pulls herself up and moves
Christine walks past the door to his bedroom. Looks insid Goes over to the bed. Her hand lingers, touching it, UNDE
Are you sure you're ready for this, Christine?
Christine and Mr. Harris, the floor manager, approach the doors to the switchboard room.
I mean, if you need more time --

The police are doing all they can, and frankly I could use the money. It's been almost a month, and...it wouldn't do any good to find Walter and bring him home if he doesn't have a home to come back to, right?
Of course.
He smiles as he says it, but there's the sense that he do think Walter's coming back. It's been too long. She sense it, but moves past it, pushing open the door and entering

As loud as before...until the operators see Christine, an the noise stops. She tries to smile, as if to say, I'm ok but can't quite manage it. CHANGELING A True Story Several women approach and hug her as the noise level beg to climb, but nowhere near what it was a moment earlier.
Well...I'll leave you to it, then.
She nods as he exits, then heads off herself.

Christine moves from station to station, the noise level noticeably low. Every time she approaches an operator, th lower their voices, as if not to bother her. One operator holds up a pink request sheet. Christine sta toward her, but then the operator glances to another supe and hands it off. Knowing she has to do something about t she turns to the room and, in a firm, clear voice, says:
Excuse me, can I have your attention?
The room grows quiet.   Everyone is looking at her.

Listen, everyone, I appreciate your consideration, but I'm not made of porcelain. I won't break down and cry if the station to station call to Kankakee doesn't go through. (a thin smile) Actually, I...promised myself that I wouldn't cry...wouldn't let myself cry...until I knew, one way or another, what.... (beat) Point is...I like the noise here. So don't be afraid to talk and...push buttons, and drop things. If it wasn't noisy, how would I know I was in the right place?
She manages a thin smile as the place returns to normal.
Mr. Harris steps out into the lunch area where a number o the operators and supervisors are hanging out.
Excuse me, has anyone seen Christine?
I think I saw her in the back office.
He nods his thanks, and continues off. CHANGELING A True Story
He approaches the door, slowing as he HEARS Christine ins
-- well, if you do hear anything, would you let me know? Thanks, I appreciate it. Goodbye.
A hang-up, then dialing.   He glances in the open doorway Christine sits at a table, phone in hand, a list of phone numbers in front of her. The list reads LAS VEGAS MISSING

head_text.subj: PERSONS DEPARTMENT, SACRAMENTO MISSING PERSONS DEPARTMENT

text: SAN FRANCISCO MISSING PERSONS DEPARTMENT...on and on...wi each having multiple checks beside it, indicating all the times she's called. Her lunch sits untouched beside her. She puts a check next to LAS VEGAS MISSING PERSONS DEPART then looks up as someone answers at the other end of the

Missing Persons department, please. (beat) Yes, hello, this is Christine Collins, I...yes, fine, thank you. I was just checking back to see if you had found any missing or lost children that might match the -- (beat) I see. No, I appreciate that, it's just...it never hurts to make sure all the lines of communication are working. I mean, that's what I do for a living, right? (beat) Well, I'll try back next week. If you do hear anything in the meantime, would you be sure to let me know? Thanks. Goodbye.
She hangs up and ticks another department off the list an dials again. Mr. Harris heads away, deciding that whateve it was he planned to talk to her about...it can wait.
Missing persons department, please.
A single car is parked in the dirt lot outside the small, roadside diner.
CHANGELING A True Story

THe COOK who owns this dive is cleaning the griddle and k an eye on the only two customers in the place: a MAN and young BOY, both wearing hats, as was the custom. They're unkempt, dirty, like they've been on the road a long time They finish the last of the food as the cook approaches, off the bill and puts it on the table.
Two dollars.
The Man reaches for his wallet.   Pats an empty pocket. the other pocket. Nothing.
Hell...looks like I left my wallet at home. Can I owe it to you?
No credit. Pay up or I call the cops. I'm tired of bums like you coming around here.
I'm not trying to stiff you, chief. I just left my wallet at home, that's all. I'll go back and get it. Five, ten minutes tops.
The Cook hesitates; he doesn't want the trouble of bringi in the cops, but he doesn't want to get stuck, either.
You got any collateral?
The Man glances at the Boy seated beside him.   The boy's is dirty, partially obscured by the hat.
Can't ask for better collateral than a man's own flesh and blood, right? (to the boy) You stay here, son, I'll be right back.
But --
Now don't give me any trouble. He's a good man to trust us like this. You just sit here while I go get my wallet. Okay?
CHANGELING A True Story The boy nods reluctantly, looks away as the man rises.
Ten minutes, then I'm calling the cops.
The Man nods, exits and drives off.     The Cook squints at the Boy, then at the wall clock.     It's 2:00.
No car.   Just the empty parking lot.
It's 3:15. The Cook is annoyed.      He glances to the Bo won't meet his gaze. Finally:
Ah, hell....
He goes to the phone.    Clicks the receiver a few times.
Hello, Myrtle? It's Harve, down by the diner. Would you get me Sheriff Larsen? Yeah, I'll wait.
He casts a sour look in the boy's direction.
What's your name, son?    Son...?
The boy takes a BEAT, looking out at the road.    Then:
I don't remember.
Swell.

As before, Christine hurries from one station to another, lost in the barely-managed chaos. She stops at one statio glancing over papers, then looks over at -- -- the window to Mr. Harris' office, where he is talking a police officer, CAPTAIN J. J. JONES, 30s, serious, arch She slows, unable to look away, a growing dread settling her heart. Harris points out the window. Points...to her. The police captain nods and enters the switchboard room. As Jones heads for her, the strength goes out of Christin legs. She holds onto the a desk as he stops before her. CHANGELING A True Story
Mrs. Collins?
She manages a nod. Behind her eyes is the terror: he's go to tell me my son is dead. The room gets very quiet.

My name is Captain J. J. Jones, Lincoln Park Juvenile Division. My office supervises all runaway and missing child cases, including your son's, and.... (beat, a smile) He's alive, Mrs. Collins. He was picked up two days ago by local police in De Kalb, Illinois. He's safe and unhurt. He was in the company of some drifter, we've got an APB out for him now, and --

But she hasn't heard anything past he's safe and unhurt. almost goes to the floor as other women rush toward her, and embracing her. For the first time, Christine cries, great wracking sobs, the emotion she's been fighting back all this time coming at last...he's okay...he's okay.
Jones and Christine are in a police car pulling up to the train station. It moves through a police line holding bac crowd of reporters who SHOUT questions at the passing car
All these reporters...you didn't tell me --
Yours is a story with a happy ending, Mrs. Collins. People love happy endings. (checks watch) Train should be pulling in shortly. We'd better get a move on.
As Christine and Jones step out, they're mobbed by the pr Jones smiles splendidly for the cameras, waves, one arm w around Christine, who looks stunned by it all.
Thank you...we'll have a statement for you in a little while. (more)
CHANGELING A True Story JONES (Cont'd) Right now the important thing is to re-unite this little lady with her son. So if you'll excuse us....
Beaming, Jones escorts Christine into Union Station.
Seated on a bench is a POLICE MATRON, and beside her, the from the De Kalb diner...who we will identify henceforth "Walter." He is looking out the window at the passing sce
Did you know that Los Angeles is where they make the Tom Mix movies?
No, I didn't.
His horse is named Blue. (beat) You think they'll let me watch them make a movie?
I don't know, you'll have to ask. But with all this attention, who knows, maybe they will.
The boy turns his attention back out the window as we HEA the WHISTLE of the train pulling into Union Station.
We HEAR the same train whistle from this side as Christin and Jones come to the ramp, POLICE CHIEF DAVIS is waiting The reporters are held back at the entrance to the platfo
Mrs. Collins, I'd like to introduce you to Chief of Police James E. Davis.
Oh, my, I didn't expect --
We don't get a lot of positive attention from the boys in the press these days, so it's good to be here when there's a positive story, don't you think?
CHANGELING A True Story But she's distracted, looking off to the end of the platf where the train is starting to pull in.
I take it you've been treated well by my boys in the department?
Oh...yes, of course, they've been great. Well, there was that part about having to wait twenty-four hours before filing a report, but --
Technicalities aside --
The train stops.    Doors begin to open.
Yes...other than that, no complaints. They've all been wonderful.
Good, then you won't have any problem telling that to the press, and how the LAPD is concerned first and foremost with the safety of --
But she's already running down the platform as people sta to step off the train. Jones exchanges a look with Davis.
Women.    Just a sec....

He trots off to catch up with Christine, who walks alongs the train, looking from window to window, anxious, eager. Then: the Matron gets off the train, her frame momentaril blocking the view of the boy beside her...but Christine s them. With Jones not far behind, she breaks into a run.
Walter...Walter!

She runs toward them. The matron turns, sees her, smiles gets out of the way, revealing the boy. Christine stops. Staggers so hard she almost falls. She steps forward slowly, a hand going to her mouth. For a mo we're not sure what's going through her mind. She looks t the matron, who smiles. Looks to the boy, who smiles. Then she steps back a pace, horror sinking in as Jones co jauntily alongside her. CHANGELING A True Story
Well?   Aren't you going to --
He's not my son.
Jones freezes at the words.
I...what are you --
He's not my son. (beat) He's not my son.
I'm...I'm sure you're mistaken.
Mistaken?
He's been through four long, terrible months...he's gone through changes, lost weight --
I know my own son.
He glances over his shoulder to where the Chief of Police waiting, not aware of any of this, and beyond him...the p
I'm just saying...I mean, you're in shock, and he's changed, and --
He turns from her, stoops down to look at the boy.
What's your name, son?   Can you tell me your name?
Walter Collins.
Christine steps back as though slapped.     This can't be
It's a common name, it --
Do you know where you live, Walter? Do you know your home address?
The boy considers for a moment...then: CHANGELING A True Story
My house is at 210 North Avenue 23, Los Angeles, California. (beat) And that's my Mommy!

And he RUNS to her, grabbing her around the waist, which magnifies her horror. Jones has no idea what to make of h or this, or the boy. The only thing he knows is that the chief of police is standing right over there, smiling now that he thinks he's seen a mother and child reunion. The press is nearly insane trying to get through to them.

Mrs. Collins...listen to me. I know you're feeling uncertain right now, but that's to be expected...a boy this age changes so fast...but we've compensated for that in our investigation. We're experts in child identification. There's no question that this is your son.
It's not Walter.
It's not Walter as you remember him. That's why it's important for you to take him home, on a...trial basis.
A trial basis?

Once you've put him back in familiar surroundings, and given yourself time to recover from the shock of his changed condition...you'll see that it is him. I swear to you, Mrs. Collins. I give you my word. Trust me...this is your son.

She looks from him to the boy...who is not terribly dissi from Walter...so that even the audience may not be entire sure if it's him or not...and part of her wants desperate to believe...the pressure is immense.
If there's any problem, any problem at all, come and talk to me and I'll take care of it. (beat) Mrs. Collins...he has nowhere else to go.
CHANGELING A True Story It's an agonizing moment, then finally:
I...look, I'll take him home, but only because I...might not be thinking clearly right now, and --
Thank you.

Without giving her a moment to reconsider, he waves and t Chief of Police approaches as the press rushes toward the In an instant, they're overwhelmed by people shouting questions, flashbulbs popping, a fever of excitement.
How does it feel to have your son home, Mrs. Collins? What did you think when you saw him for the first time?
It was...it's...hard to explain.
